QAPair.Question: What is (are) Coloboma of the iris ?
QAPair.Answer: Coloboma of the iris is a hole or defect of the iris of the eye. Most colobomas are present since birth (congenital).

QAPair.Question: What to do for Coloboma of the iris ?
QAPair.Answer: Coloboma of the iris can look like a second pupil or a black notch at the edge of the pupil. This gives the pupil an irregular shape. It can also appear as a split in the iris from the pupil to the edge of the iris. A small coloboma (especially if it is not attached to the pupil) may allow a second image to focus on the back of the eye. This may cause: Blurred vision, Decreased visual acuity , Double vision, Ghost image , If it is congenital, the defect may include the retina , choroid , or optic nerve. Most colobomas are diagnosed at birth or shortly afterward.

QAPair.Question: What causes Coloboma of the iris ?
QAPair.Answer: Most cases of coloboma have no known cause and are not related to other abnormalities. Some are due to a specific genetic defect. A small number of people with coloboma have other inherited developmental problems.

Question.qtype: when to contact a medical professional

QAPair.Question: Do I need to see a doctor for Coloboma of the iris ?
QAPair.Answer: Contact your health care provider if: You notice that your child has what appears to be a hole in the iris or an unusual-shaped pupil., Your child's vision becomes blurred or decreased. , In addition to your child, you may also need to see an eye specialist (ophthalmologist).
